elements.content: The exploring of oxygen electrocatalysts with outstanding durability and efficiency toward the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is greatly desired for zinc-air flow batteries (ZAFBs). Herein, NiCo alloy-based nanoparticles anchored on carbon nanotube-decorated carbon nanorods (CNRs) used as a durable and efficient oxygen electrocatalyst for ZAFBs were obtained from the pyrolysis of NiCo metal–organic frameworks synthesized by a facile oil bath method. By tailoring the ratio of Ni2+ and Co2+, the prepared sample, Ni2Co2-CNR, exhibits excellent ORR (E 1/2 = 0.80 V) and OER catalytic performances (a low overpotential of 310 mV at 10 mA cm–2). Impressively, the ZAFB assembled with a Ni2Co2-CNR catalyst shows a narrow voltage gap and remarkable operation durability with 1200 cycles at 5 mA cm–2 with every cycle of 20 min.

elements.content: Nowadays, the seeking for advanced electrical energy storage devices has never stopped in the post-lithium-ion battery era because of the limited energy density of Li-ion batteries that only come up to about 100–250 W h kg–1. As a battery technique, metal-air flow batteries with the features of the structural design of conventional redox flow batteries from static metal-air batteries, including lithium-air, sodium-air, vanadium-air, and zinc-air flow batteries (ZAFBs), show tremendous potential in highly efficient energy storage technology and have attracted intensive attention recently. However, all the abovementioned flow batteries involve two important reactions at their cathodes including the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) whose sluggish kinetics rates limit their conversion efficiencies. Therefore, it is urgently necessary to explore an ideal electrocatalysts for ORR/OER with favorable stability, making the ZAFB display high power density and excellent cycling stability.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Nowadays, the seeking for advanced electrical energy storage devices has never stopped in the post-lithium-ion battery era because of the limited energy density of Li-ion batteries that only come up to about 100-250 W h kg-1. As a battery technique, metal-air flow batteries with the features of the structural design of conventional redox flow batteries from static metal-air batteries, including lithium-air, sodium-air, vanadium-air, and zinc-air flow batteries (ZAFBs), show tremendous potential in highly efficient energy storage technology and have attracted intensive attention recently. However, all the abovementioned flow batteries involve two important reactions at their cathodes including the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) whose sluggish kinetics rates limit their conversion efficiencies. Therefore, it is urgently necessary to explore an ideal electrocatalysts for ORR/OER with favorable stability, making the ZAFB display high power density and excellent cycling stability.

elements.content: Recently, nonprecious bimetallic materials (such as metal alloys), particularly, transition metal, have gained noticeable attention as candidates for oxygen electrocatalysts due to their highly active catalytic trait toward ORR and OER. An army of reported works has indicated that the bimetallic alloy catalysts display excellent electrocatalysis compared to their individual entity. The credit goes to the synergetic electronic interactions between the participating elements. The bonding from two different metals establishes an intrinsic polarity, resulting in enhanced catalytic reaction rates.
elements.clean_text: Recently, nonprecious bimetallic materials (such as metal alloys), particularly, transition metal, have gained noticeable attention as candidates for oxygen electrocatalysts due to their highly active catalytic trait toward ORR and OER. An army of reported works has indicated that the bimetallic alloy catalysts display excellent electrocatalysis compared to their individual entity. The credit goes to the synergetic electronic interactions between the participating elements. The bonding from two different metals establishes an intrinsic polarity, resulting in enhanced catalytic reaction rates.

elements.content: However, non-supported metal alloy materials cannot exhibit excellent bifunctional catalytic performances because of the tendency to form oxides, resulting in lower conductivity. Therefore, combining alloy nanoparticles with carbon materials with features of excellent stability, superior electrical conductivity, and high surface area is a commonly used means to not only protect the metal alloy nanoparticles from agglomeration but also improve the catalytic activity of alloy-based materials, which favors boosting of the number of active sites and supplying electron conduction channels.

Therefore, combining alloy nanoparticles with carbon materials with features of excellent stability, superior electrical conductivity, and high surface area is a commonly used means to not only protect the metal alloy nanoparticles from agglomeration but also improve the catalytic activity of alloy-based materials, which favors boosting of the number of active sites and supplying electron conduction channels.

elements.content: Metal organic frameworks (MOFs) have been widely regarded as precursors to manufacture carbon-based bifunctional electrocatalysts. Its outstanding performance is mainly attributed to the porous framework and the diversity of structures and functions. ZIF-67 and ZIF-8 are commonly used MOF materials. However, they only have one kind of metal element. Also, it is difficult for them to form metal alloys. NiCo-74, as one of the MOF materials, contains both Ni and Co elements and can generate NiCo alloys during the calcination process. In addition, NiCo-74 materials can be catalyzed by its own Ni element to form carbon nanotubes (CNTs) in the process of calcination, improving the conductivity of the final materials. Among all kinds of alloys, the NiCo alloy nanoparticles also exhibit tremendous potential because they possess affluent valence state changes supplied by them, which is beneficial for the process of ORR and OER. Furthermore, the earth abundance as well as environmental friendliness of nickel and cobalt may contribute to their heavy use. As an example, Li et al. reported a preferable bifunctional electrocatalyst for ORR and OER, which is composed of carbon nanotubes anchored with NiCo alloy nanoparticles.

However, they only have one kind of metal element. Also, it is difficult for them to form metal alloys. NiCo-74, as one of the MOF materials, contains both Ni and Co elements and can generate NiCo alloys during the calcination process. In addition, NiCo-74 materials can be catalyzed by its own Ni element to form carbon nanotubes (CNTs) in the process of calcination, improving the conductivity of the final materials. Among all kinds of alloys, the NiCo alloy nanoparticles also exhibit tremendous potential because they possess affluent valence state changes supplied by them, which is beneficial for the process of ORR and OER. As an example, Li et al. reported a preferable bifunctional electrocatalyst for ORR and OER, which is composed of carbon nanotubes anchored with NiCo alloy nanoparticles.

elements.content: Inspired by the above, in this article, a highly efficient, low-cost, and stable bifunctional electrocatalyst containing NiCo alloy nanoparticles and a small fraction of CNTs, which are tightly anchored and decorated on carbon nanorods, respectively, (Ni x Co y -CNR), is presented. Also, the whole synthetic process is overwhelmingly simple and facile, which only involves an oil bath method and subsequent calcination. The hybrid catalyst with a suitable ratio of Ni2+and Co2+ (Ni2Co2-CNR) shows positive electrocatalytic activities and stability toward ORR (E 1/2 = 0.80 V) and OER (a low overpotential of 310 mV to reach 10 mA cm–2) compared to the 20 wt % Pt/C and IrO2 catalysts, respectively. What is most impressive is that when Ni2Co2-CNR is integrated into the ZAFB, a high peak power density (122.1 mW cm–2) and energy density (784.5 mA h gZn –1) can be achieved. In addition, ZAFBs fabricated with Ni2Co2-CNR also exhibit an anticipated long-time cycling performance without obvious decay (1200 cycles at 5 mA cm–2 with every cycle of 20 mins). The synergetic effects that stem from the carbon framework (carbon nanorods and CNTs) and NiCo alloy nanoparticles are considered as the major contributions for the enhanced electrocatalytic activity.

Also, the whole synthetic process is overwhelmingly simple and facile, which only involves an oil bath method and subsequent calcination. The hybrid catalyst with a suitable ratio of Ni2+and Co2+ (Ni2Co2-CNR) shows positive electrocatalytic activities and stability toward ORR (E 1/2 = 0.80 V) and OER (a low overpotential of 310 mV to reach 10 mA cm-2) compared to the 20 wt % Pt/C and IrO2 catalysts, respectively. elements.content: The synthesis of NiCo-MOF was based on published literature with some modification. First, a total of 4 mmol of two metallic acetates (Ni­(CH3COO)2·4H2O/Co­(CH3COO)2·4H2O) and 2 mmol 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (DHTA) were dissolved in 50 mL of deionized water, respectively. Then, the solution containing metallic acetate was dropped into another solution containing DHTA with slow continuous magnetic stirring (15 min). Finally, the mixed solution was put into a round-bottom flask followed by magnetic stirring at 100 °C for 60 min. After cooling down to room temperature, earth-yellow sediments were obtained after centrifugation and washed with deionized water and ethanol several times (7500 rpm for 5 min), respectively. During the feeding process, by tailoring the ratio of Ni2+ and Co2+, NiCo-MOF nanorods with different chemical compositions can be obtained, which were named Ni x Co y -MOF (x:y = 4:0, 3:1, 2:2, 1:3, and 0:4).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of NiCo-MOF Nanorods

The synthesis of NiCo-MOF was based on published literature with some modification. First, a total of 4 mmol of two metallic acetates (Ni(CH3COO)2⋅4H2O/Co(CH3COO)2⋅4H2O) and 2 mmol 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (DHTA) were dissolved in 50 mL of deionized water, respectively. Then, the solution containing metallic acetate was dropped into another solution containing DHTA with slow continuous magnetic stirring (15 min). Finally, the mixed solution was put into a round-bottom flask followed by magnetic stirring at 100 °C for 60 min. After cooling down to room temperature, earth-yellow sediments were obtained after centrifugation and washed with deionized water and ethanol several times (7500 rpm for 5 min), respectively. During the feeding process, by tailoring the ratio of Ni2+ and Co2+, NiCo-MOF nanorods with different chemical compositions can be obtained, which were named Ni x Co y -MOF (x:y = 4:0, 3:1, 2:2, 1:3, and 0:4).

elements.content: The as-prepared Ni x Co y -MOF powders were subjected to direct pyrolysis at 900 °C for 120 min under a N2 environment with a heating rate of 5 °C min–1 to obtain black powders. During pyrolysis at high temperature, Ni2+ from Ni x Co y -MOF can catalyze the formation of CNTs on the surface of Ni x Co y -MOF because of the easier reduction of Ni2+ than Co2+ by carbothermal reduction. Simultaneously, Ni2+ and Co2+ can generate the NiCo alloy. Also, the entire morphology of Ni x Co y -MOF can be retained. Finally, we obtained carbon nanorods decorated and anchored with CNTs and NiCo alloy nanoparticles, respectively, (denoted as Ni x Co y -CNR).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Ni x Co y -CNR

The as-prepared Ni x Co y -MOF powders were subjected to direct pyrolysis at 900 °C for 120 min under a N2 environment with a heating rate of 5 °C min-1 to obtain black powders. During pyrolysis at high temperature, Ni2+ from Ni x Co y -MOF can catalyze the formation of CNTs on the surface of Ni x Co y -MOF because of the easier reduction of Ni2+ than Co2+ by carbothermal reduction. Simultaneously, Ni2+ and Co2+ can generate the NiCo alloy. Also, the entire morphology of Ni x Co y -MOF can be retained. Finally, we obtained carbon nanorods decorated and anchored with CNTs and NiCo alloy nanoparticles, respectively, (denoted as Ni x Co y -CNR).

elements.content: describes the overall synthetic process of the Ni x Co y -MOF series and their derivatives (Ni x Co y -CNR). Ni x Co y -MOF nanorods were obtained by a co-precipitation reaction between different ratios of Ni2+/Co2+ and DHTA. After pyrolysis at 900 °C, Ni x Co y -MOF nanorods were converted into carbon nanorods decorated with NiCo alloy nanoparticles (Ni x Co y -CNR). Table S1 displays the Ni and Co content from the ICP measurement. It can be observed that the results are in accordance with the feed ratio. In addition, the reduction of Ni2+/Co2+ can lead to the formation of CNTs on the surface of Ni x Co y -CNR, generating the three-dimensional (3D) interconnected network architecture of Ni x Co y -CNR.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural and Morphological Characterization

  describes the overall synthetic process of the Ni x Co y -MOF series and their derivatives (Ni x Co y -CNR). Ni x Co y -MOF nanorods were obtained by a co-precipitation reaction between different ratios of Ni2+/Co2+ and DHTA. After pyrolysis at 900 °C, Ni x Co y -MOF nanorods were converted into carbon nanorods decorated with NiCo alloy nanoparticles (Ni x Co y -CNR). Table S1 displays the Ni and Co content from the ICP measurement. It can be observed that the results are in accordance with the feed ratio. In addition, the reduction of Ni2+/Co2+ can lead to the formation of CNTs on the surface of Ni x Co y -CNR, generating the three-dimensional (3D) interconnected network architecture of Ni x Co y -CNR.

elements.content: The unique morphology of the prepared Ni x Co y -MOF samples with different Ni2+/Co2+ ratios was examined by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM). As displayed in a–e, the five samples have quintessentially rod-like shapes with a smooth surface and different lengths and diameters. It is also interesting to observe that the length of rods gradually decreases ranging from about 5.5 to 0.5 μm with the increase in the ratio of Ni2+/Co2+, possibly ascribed to Co atoms improving the crystal growth along a particular lattice plane and limiting the growth in other lattice planes. k shows the powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the as-obtained Ni x Co y -MOF. Obviously, they match well with the simulated XRD pattern of Ni-74 from the single-crystal data and the previously reported results, demonstrating the successful synthesis of the NiCo-MOF sample. Moreover, the intensity of these XRD patterns apparently decreases with the decreased Ni contents within these NiCo-MOF samples, indicating the different crystallinity degrees and sizes of the obtained samples.

elements.content: Second, the microstructure of the abovementioned samples after pyrolysis at 900 °C for 2 h was first investigated by SEM. As shown in f–j, Ni x Co y -CNR maintains the original rod-like shape of Ni x Co y -MOF and the aspect ratio of Ni x Co y -CNR is in accordance with that of Ni x Co y -MOF. Besides the change of aspect ratio, different lengths and densities of CNTs on the surface of carbon nanorods are also observed due to the variation of the Ni2+/Co2+ ratio. Clearly, when the ratio of Ni2+/Co2+ is 2:2, Ni2Co2-CNR has the highest density of CNTs on the surface of carbon rods. There are two reasons accounting for the above result. One is that Ni nanoparticles are easy to aggregate compared to Co nanoparticles and more Co nanoparticles are introduced into NiCo-MOF to reduce the aggregation of Ni nanoparticles to some extent, easily facilitating the formation of CNTs on the surface of carbon nanorods. The other reason is attributed to the easier reduction of Ni2+ than Co2+. This can be confirmed from i,j. Ni1Co3-CNR displays little CNTs on its surface compared to Ni2Co2-CNR. However, with the continued reduction of Ni2+ until totally being replaced by Co2+, CNTs could not be captured from the surface of Ni0Co4-CNR, confirming the weaker reduction of Co2+ than Ni2+.

elements.content: The XRD patterns obtained from five different samples are presented in l. Ni4Co0-CNR without the addition of Co2+ displays a pure Ni phase and its three distinctive peaks located at 44.5, 51.8, and 76.3° are assigned to the (111), (200), and (220) planes of Ni (PDF#04-0850), indicating that Ni2+ from the precursor of Ni4Coy-MOF is successfully reduced to Ni nanoparticles during the process of calcination. Subsequently, after the introduction of Co2+ in the synthetic steps, the diffraction peaks of the obtained three samples (Ni3Co1-CNR, Ni2Co2-CNR, and Ni1Co3-CNR) shift to lower angles and are located between those of Co (PDF#15-0806) and Ni (PDF#04-0850), demonstrating the formation of single-phase alloyed NiCo nanoparticles. Although the information concerning carbon peaks is not discovered from the XRD results, this phenomenon does not manifest the inexistence of carbon components. Obviously, the Raman spectrum of the five samples is diagnostic of the presence of carbon species. As shown in m, all samples display two peaks centered at about 1335 cm–1 (D-band) and 1585 cm–1 (G-band), respectively. The D-band and G-band derive from the defective carbon (sp3) and graphite carbon (sp2) atoms, respectively. The ratio of I D/I G of Ni2Co2-CNR is 1.01, smaller than those of Ni4Co0-CNR (1.04), Ni3Co1-CNR (1.21), Ni1Co3-CNR (1.06), and Ni0Co4-CNR (1.04), indicative of the improved degree of graphitization of Ni2Co2-CNR. The boosted degree of graphitization is expected to trigger an enhanced electrical conductivity, which favors acceleration of the charge transfer rate during the electrolysis.

elements.content: The morphology of the Ni x Co y -CNR series was also probed via TEM technology. As displayed in a–e, the rod-like configurations of Ni x Co y -CNR are retained well during the annealing process, which is consistent with the SEM images. At the same time, a host of black and small sized nanoparticles is homogeneously anchored on carbon nanorods, without apparent agglomeration, demonstrating a good dispersion in the carbon structure. In addition, CNTs decorated on carbon nanorods can also be clearly observed (b–d). Also, the CNTs on the carbon nanorods and adjacent carbon nanorods and CNTs can form a 3D interconnected network structure, serving not only as conduction paths for shuttling electrons but also active sites for the catalytic process. It is noteworthy that Ni0Co4-CNR displays no CNTs on its surface (e), validating the above phenomenon. f–j shows the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images of Ni x Co y -CNR. The lattice fringe spacings are 0.203 nm (f), 0.215 nm (g–i), and 0.204 nm (j), which are ascribed to the (111) crystal planes of the Ni, NiCo alloy, and Co, respectively. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern of Ni2Co2-CNR corroborate that it is polycrystalline (l), consistent with the HRTEM observation. Furthermore, elemental mapping images of Ni2Co2-CNR (k) disclose the well-defined spatial distribution of C, O, Ni, and Co in the sample.

elements.content: XPS was conducted to investigate the chemical composition of all catalysts. As shown in a, the XPS overall survey spectra confirm the existence of C, O, Ni, and Co elements of Ni3Co1-CNR, Ni2Co2-CNR, and Ni1Co3-CNR. Especially for Ni2Co2-CNR, it includes 4.58, 3.98, 87.45, and 3.99 at % Ni, Co, C, and O, respectively, based on the XPS results (Table S2), which is close to the feeding composition in its precursors. Furthermore, it can be observed that the intensity of the Co peak becomes weaker with the reduction of the Co ratio from Ni0Co4-CNR to Ni4Co0-CNR. In contrast, the intensity of the Ni peak becomes strong with the reduction of the Co ratio from Ni0Co4-CNR to Ni4Co0-CNR, which is also in accordance with the feed ratio of Ni2+/Co2+.

elements.content: The high-resolution of the Co 2p spectrum of Ni0Co4-CNR (b) can be fitted into four components, which are Co0 (779.42 eV and 794.44 eV), Co3+ (795.37 and 780.66 eV), Co2+ (782.48 and 797.54 eV), and satellite structure (786.56 and 803.08 eV). Meanwhile, the peaks of Co0 from Ni1Co3-CNR, Ni2Co2-CNR, and Ni3Co1-CNR were shifted to lower binding energies of about 1.09, 0.75, and 0.71 eV, respectively, with respect to the monometallic Ni0Co4-CNR. Such an observed shift reflects a modification of the electronic structure between the near-surface Co and Ni atoms. It also demonstrates the formation of the NiCo alloy and the existence of bimetallic synergic effects. Such a phenomenon can also be verified from the high-resolution Ni 2p spectra of all samples. As shown in c, the high-resolution Ni 2p spectrum of Ni4Co0-CNR can also be deconvoluted into eight peaks, displaying four Ni species. The peaks at 852.61 and 870.98 eV are attributed to Ni0 in the NiCo alloy. The peaks located at 853.77 and 873.47 eV correspond to Ni3+ the peaks at 855.74 and 877.97 eV are consistent with those of Ni2+, and the other peaks located at 860.70 and 880.81 eV are assigned to the satellite structure. Similarly, the peaks of Ni0 from Ni3Co1-CNR, Ni2Co2-CNR, and Ni1Co3-CNR were also shifted to lower binding energies of about 0.01, 0.39, and 0.03 eV, respectively, confirming the presence of NiCo alloy. Ascribed to the formation of the NiCo alloy, the Co atoms can obtain d electrons from the nearby Ni atoms, increasing the electron-donating feature of the hybrids, which may improve the electrochemical activity. d shows the high-resolution O 1s spectrum, and the peaks at 529.88 and 531.58 eV are attributed to oxygen species.

elements.content: e,f displays the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm and the corresponding pore diameter distribution curves of Ni x Co y -CNR. Obviously, they all exhibit a typical type IV hysteresis loop, confirming the existence of micro/mesoporosity in the as-synthesized catalysts. In addition, the specific surface area (SSA) and the maximum pore width of Ni2Co2-CNR are measured to be 154.93 m2 g–1 and 23.1 nm, respectively. Also, the sample of Ni0Co4-CNR has no pores according to the pore diameter distribution curve. The mesoporous structure has a positive impact on the mass transfer and rapid diffusion of O2, thus providing a highly accessible surface area and more active sites for the electrolysis.

elements.content: To assess catalytic performance toward ORR, the five samples’ powder as well as 20% Pt/C were tested for linear sweeping voltammograms (LSV) in O2-bubbled 0.1 M KOH solution with a rotation speed of 1600 rpm at a scan rate of 5 mV s–1. As displayed in a and Table S3, without the addition Co2+ in the precursor, even the diffusion limiting current density of Ni4Co0-CNR does not achieve −4 mA cm–2, whereas after the introduction of Co2+ in the precursor, Ni3Co1-CNR, Ni2Co2-CNR, and Ni1Co3-CNR can reach higher values above −4 mA cm–2, indicating that the synergetic effects between NiCo alloy nanoparticles and carbon nanorods can enhance ORR performance. More remarkably, Ni2Co2-CNR shows pleasurable ORR catalytic activity confirmed by the limiting current density (−5.15 mA cm–2) and half-wave potential (E 1/2 = 0.80 V) being more positive than those of Ni4Co0-CNR, Ni3Co1-CNR, and Ni1Co3-CNR, although they are slightly lower than those of 20% Pt/C. However, with the continuous increase of Co2+ until Ni2+ is totally replaced by Co2+, the limiting current density of Ni0Co4-CNR is still unsatisfactory. All the above discussions demonstrate that Ni2Co2-CNR possesses the best ORR electrocatalytic performances. The excellent ORR activity of Ni2Co2-CNR can further be verified by the Tafel slope displayed in b. It can be seen that the Tafel slope of Ni2Co2-CNR is 83 mV/dec, much lower than that of Ni4Co0-CNR (150 mV/dec), Ni3Co1-CNR (138 mV/dec), Ni1Co3-CNR (123 mV/dec), and Ni0Co4-CNR (127 mV/dec) and even comparable to that of Pt/C (70 mV/dec), which validates the preferable kinetic process of Ni2Co2-CNR toward ORR. The prominent ORR performance of Ni2Co2-CNR may be attributed to the synergetic effects between NiCo alloy nanoparticles and carbon nanorods and high surface area and 3D interconnected network architecture stemming from carbon nanorods and CNTs.
elements.clean_text:
Electrocatalytic Properties

To assess catalytic performance toward ORR, the five samples' powder as well as 20% Pt/C were tested for linear sweeping voltammograms (LSV) in O2-bubbled 0.1 M KOH solution with a rotation speed of 1600 rpm at a scan rate of 5 mV s-1. As displayed in a and Table S3, without the addition Co2+ in the precursor, even the diffusion limiting current density of Ni4Co0-CNR does not achieve -4 mA cm-2, whereas after the introduction of Co2+ in the precursor, Ni3Co1-CNR, Ni2Co2-CNR, and Ni1Co3-CNR can reach higher values above -4 mA cm-2, indicating that the synergetic effects between NiCo alloy nanoparticles and carbon nanorods can enhance ORR performance. More remarkably, Ni2Co2-CNR shows pleasurable ORR catalytic activity confirmed by the limiting current density (-5.15 mA cm-2) and half-wave potential (E 1/2 = 0.80 V) being more positive than those of Ni4Co0-CNR, Ni3Co1-CNR, and Ni1Co3-CNR, although they are slightly lower than those of 20% Pt/C. However, with the continuous increase of Co2+ until Ni2+ is totally replaced by Co2+, the limiting current density of Ni0Co4-CNR is still unsatisfactory. All the above discussions demonstrate that Ni2Co2-CNR possesses the best ORR electrocatalytic performances. The excellent ORR activity of Ni2Co2-CNR can further be verified by the Tafel slope displayed in b. It can be seen that the Tafel slope of Ni2Co2-CNR is 83 mV/dec, much lower than that of Ni4Co0-CNR (150 mV/dec), Ni3Co1-CNR (138 mV/dec), Ni1Co3-CNR (123 mV/dec), and Ni0Co4-CNR (127 mV/dec) and even comparable to that of Pt/C (70 mV/dec), which validates the preferable kinetic process of Ni2Co2-CNR toward ORR. The prominent ORR performance of Ni2Co2-CNR may be attributed to the synergetic effects between NiCo alloy nanoparticles and carbon nanorods and high surface area and 3D interconnected network architecture stemming from carbon nanorods and CNTs.

elements.content: LSV curves of Ni2Co2-CNR at different rotating speeds were also recorded to further gain insight into the ORR kinetics shown in c and Figure S1. Obviously, as the rotation rates increase, so does the limiting current density. The inset of c presents the corresponding Koutecky–Levich (K-L) plots of Ni2Co2-CNR and the lines are linear and parallel, indicating that O2 kinetics on the Ni2Co2-CNR catalyst follows first-order reaction kinetics. Also, the calculated electron transfer number (n) is determined in the range of 3.85–3.94, indicating that a typical four-electron reaction pathway is dominat during the ORR process for Ni2Co2-CNR. The n values for other samples are displayed in Figure S2. In addition, the n and peroxide yield (HO2 – %) are obtained according to the rotating ring disk electrode (RRDE) curves. As shown in Figure S3, Ni2Co2-CNR possesses comparable values of n (3.85) at 0.7 V, which matches well with the above result (the inset of c). Furthermore, the HO2 – % for Ni2Co2-CNR is 7.48% at 0.7 V, disclosing excellent selectivity for the ORR process.

elements.content: Furthermore, the stability and durability of Ni2Co2-CNR were also tested because of their importance for the ORR reaction. Ni2Co2-CNR displays no obvious recession after adding methanol (3 M) into electrolyte, suggesting the excellent abovementioned property (d). In addition, when Ni2Co2-CNR is subjected to cyclic voltammetry (CV) tests for 4000 cycles, as presented in e, a negligible performance reduction (5 mV) negative shift toward E 1/2 is observed after tests. Figures S4 and S5 display the SEM, TEM, and corresponding mapping images after CV measurements. Clearly, many carbon rods are captured after tests, disclosing no obvious changes about its morphology. Furthermore, it is also interesting to notice that many CNTs marked in Figure S5b,c still can be observed. Figure S5d shows the homogeneous distribution of Ni and Co elements. Further, f displays the i–t curve of Ni2Co2-CNR and 20% Pt/C at a potential of 0.65 V. After about 43,000 s, the prepared catalyst can retain 84.1% of the initial current. On the other hand, its counterpart has only a relative current retention rate of 50.2%, which is ascribed to the corrosion of the amorphous carbon support and the possible Pt detachment and aggregation. In general, the above results reveal the outstanding durability and stability of Ni2Co2-CNR as an ORR electrocatalyst.

elements.content: Under the same measurement conditions, the OER performances of the NiCo alloy series and the commercial IrO2 catalyst were also investigated and are exhibited in a. It is found that Ni2Co2-CNR not only shows favorable ORR performance but also outstanding OER activity. Apparently, a 310 mV overpotential to achieve 10 mA cm–2 is afforded by the Ni2Co2-CNR, lower than that of other ratios of NiCo alloy catalysts (Table S3) and IrO2. The better performance toward OER of Ni2Co2-CNR can be also validated from the Tafel slope value of all samples shown in b. One can see that Ni2Co2-CNR possesses a Tafel slope value of 135 mV/dec, lower than those of Ni4Co0-CNR (163 mV/dec), Ni3Co1-CNR (163 mV/dec), Ni1Co3-CNR (136 mV/dec), Ni0Co4-CNR (248 mV/dec), and IrO2 (232 mV/dec). This is perhaps attributed to the higher graphitization degree of Ni2Co2-CNR (m) and optimized electronic structure between NiCo alloy nanoparticles (b,c).

elements.content: Additionally, because of the proportion between electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) and electrochemical double-layer capacitance (Cdl), CV measurements at different scan rates were conducted to calculate the value of C dl so as to further estimate ECSA. As shown in d and Figure S6, Ni2Co2-CNR displays the largest C dl determined to be 44.9 mF cm–2, higher than those of other as-synthesized samples, demonstrating that Ni2Co2-CNR can supply more active sites for redox reactions. The so many active sites of Ni2Co2-CNR is believed to be governed by its unique and abundant carbon structure including carbon rods and CNTs, which can expose more NiCo alloy sites, further resulting in remarkable OER performance.

elements.content: Likewise, the durability is also a crucial indicator to assess the performance of a catalyst toward OER. Therefore, CV cycling and i–t techniques are carried out to verify the stability of Ni2Co2-CNR. First, as displayed in e, after 4000 cycles of CV cycling, the slight change of overpotential (10 mV) is afforded by Ni2Co2-CNR. Figure S7a shows the SEM image after OER tests of Ni2Co2-CNR. It can be observed that Ni2Co2-CNR keeps its original structure with obvious carbon rods. In addition, the high-resolution Co 2p and Ni 2p spectra after OER tests of Ni2Co2-CNR were also detected and are showcased in Figure S7b,c. However, the potential to achieve 10 mA cm–2 is positively shifted by 140 mV for IrO2. Then, an i–t chronoamperometric response test is conducted and the result is presented in f. After 12 h of continuous operation, the residual current percentage of Ni2Co2-CNR is 90.4%. Consequently, Ni2Co2-CNR also possesses promising durability toward OER processes.

elements.content: To investigate the potential application of Ni2Co2-CNR in ZAFBs, the ORR and OER bifunctional performances are further characterized by the potential gap (ΔE = E OER(j = 10) – E 1/2). As displayed in c, the Ni2Co2-CNR catalyst exhibits a VG of 0.74 V, lower than that of Pt/C + IrO2 (0.86 V) and some reported transition-metal alloy-based bifunctional catalysts.

elements.content: The excellent ORR and OER electrochemical performances of Ni2Co2-CNR stimulate us to probe its potential as the air catalyst of practical ZAFBs. a and Figure S11 show the configuration of homemade ZAFBs. It includes an anode, an electrolyte, a cathode, and a pump. Due to efficient suppression of zinc dendrites by the flow electrolyte, ZAFBs have a longer cycle life than most traditional zinc air batteries.
elements.clean_text:
Performance of Zinc-Air Flow Batteries

The excellent ORR and OER electrochemical performances of Ni2Co2-CNR stimulate us to probe its potential as the air catalyst of practical ZAFBs. a and Figure S11 show the configuration of homemade ZAFBs. It includes an anode, an electrolyte, a cathode, and a pump. Due to efficient suppression of zinc dendrites by the flow electrolyte, ZAFBs have a longer cycle life than most traditional zinc air batteries.

elements.content: Scheme of the basic configuration of ZAFB (a); polarization and corresponding power density curves of ZAFB with Ni2Co2-CNR and Pt/C as air cathodes, respectively (b); discharge curves of ZAFBs using Ni2Co2-CNR and Pt/C as the air cathode catalyst at 10 mA cm–2 (c), the inset displays the photograph of the zinc plate after the battery stopped working; Galvanostatic discharge curves of the ZAFB with Ni2Co2-CNR and Pt/C at different current densities (d); specific capacities of the ZAFB assembled by Ni2Co2-CNR at 5 mA cm–2 (e); photographs of an LED panel with DHU characters and an LED bulb powered by the ZAFB with Ni2Co2-CNR as the air cathode (f); discharge–charge cycling curves of ZAFB with Ni2Co2-CNR and Pt/C + IrO2 at 5 mA cm–2 (g), the inset displays voltage values at different cycle intervals.

elements.content: Figure S8 displays a ZAFB with Ni2Co2-CNR displays an open circuit potential of 1.61 V after 600 s. b exhibits discharge polarization and corresponding power density curves for ZAFBs assembled with Ni2Co2-CNR and Pt/C + IrO2, respectively. It can be seen that the maximum power density of ZAFBs using Ni2Co2-CNR as the air electrode is 122.1 mW cm–2, higher than that of the Pt/C + IrO2-based ZAFB (93.6 mW cm–2). Galvanostatic discharge curves reveal that Pt/C-based ZAFBs can only maintain about 124.2 h under a current density of 10 mA cm–2. However, the ZAFB using Ni2Co2-CNR as the air cathode can work for more than 200 h although the discharge voltage of Ni2Co2-CNR is lower than that of Pt/C at the initial 100 h. With the continuous consumption of the zinc plate, the electrolyte of the ZAFB began to leak, resulting in the fluctuation of the curve shown in c. The inset of c shows the photograph of the zinc plate after the battery stopped working. The discharge potential plains of the ZAFB at different current densities were also tested and are showcased in d. At 10 mA cm–2, the voltage of the ZAFB equipped with Ni2Co2-CNR is lower than that of the ZAFB fabricated with Pt/C + IrO2. However, at higher current density, the voltage of Ni2Co2-CNR is apparently higher than its counterpart. Even though the current density was returned to 10 mA cm–2, the voltage rebounded to 1.17 V, disclosing a remarkable rate performance for Ni2Co2-CNR. Also, at 5 mA cm–2, the specific capacity of the ZAFB with Ni2Co2-CNR is 784.5 mA h gZn –1 by normalizing to the consumed zinc (e). f presents a ZAFB assembled with the Ni2Co2-CNR catalyst, which lightened a light-emitting diode (LED) board showing “DHU”. In addition, two ZAFB in series can light a LED bulb, demonstrating its potential application.

elements.content: Last but not least, to verify the excellent stability and durability of Ni2Co2-CNR, the galvanostatic cycling test of ZAFBs is further investigated with every cycle of 20 min. As shown in g, at 5 mA cm–2, the battery assembled by Pt/C + IrO2 fails quickly with a limited cyclability of 237 cycles (79 h). However, the battery fabricated by Ni2Co2-CNR displays an outstanding durability for 1200 cycles (400 h). Although, at the first cycle, the VG of Pt/C + IrO2 is 0.83 V (Figure S9), a little lower than that of the Ni2Co2-CNR-based battery (0.85 V) showcased in the inset of g. This may be attributed to the better ORR and OER catalytic activity from Pt/C and IrO2, respectively. Nevertheless, with the increment of cycles, the VG of Pt/C + IrO2 grows to 0.98 V after 200 cycles due to the poor stability of Pt/C or IrO2 while the VG of the battery assembled by Ni2Co2-CNR only reaches to 0.93 V at 500 cycles (the inset of g). This may be ascribed to the compatibility adjusted by the original charging and discharging operation, enhancing the sufficient electrochemical reaction, which is in favor of cycling performance. Consequently, even at 1200 cycles, the VG is merely 1.04 V (the inset of g). Figure S10 displays the SEM images of Ni2Co2-CNR after cycling tests. It can be clearly observed that Ni2Co2-CNR still retains the original rod-like shape, which is in accordance with the initial SEM images (h), demonstrating the prominent stability and durability of Ni2Co2-CNR.
elements.clean_text: Last but not least, to verify the excellent stability and durability of Ni2Co2-CNR, the galvanostatic cycling test of ZAFBs is further investigated with every cycle of 20 min. As shown in g, at 5 mA cm-2, the battery assembled by Pt/C + IrO2 fails quickly with a limited cyclability of 237 cycles (79 h). However, the battery fabricated by Ni2Co2-CNR displays an outstanding durability for 1200 cycles (400 h). Although, at the first cycle, the VG of Pt/C + IrO2 is 0.83 V (Figure S9), a little lower than that of the Ni2Co2-CNR-based battery (0.85 V) showcased in the inset of g. elements.content: In summary, here, we report a durable and efficient oxygen electrocatalyst composed of NiCo alloy nanoparticles anchored on CNT-decorated carbon nanorods. By adjusting the ratio of Ni2+ and Co2+, the synthesized Ni2Co2-CNR catalyst possesses prominent ORR and OER properties. In addition, zinc-air flow batteries (ZAFBs) fabricated with Ni2Co2-CNR shows a power density of 122.1 mW cm–2 as well as brilliant cyclability (1200 cycles for 400 h). The synergetic effects between NiCo alloy nanoparticles and the role of CNTs and carbon nanorods are believed to be the major contribution for the improved catalytic activities, including excellent conductivity, dispersed active sites, optimized electronic structure, and three-dimensional (3D) interconnected network structure. This work will facilitate the development of bimetallic alloy-based materials toward ORR and OER electrocatalysts with features of durability, inexpensiveness, and efficiency.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, here, we report a durable and efficient oxygen electrocatalyst composed of NiCo alloy nanoparticles anchored on CNT-decorated carbon nanorods. By adjusting the ratio of Ni2+ and Co2+, the synthesized Ni2Co2-CNR catalyst possesses prominent ORR and OER properties. In addition, zinc-air flow batteries (ZAFBs) fabricated with Ni2Co2-CNR shows a power density of 122.1 mW cm-2 as well as brilliant cyclability (1200 cycles for 400 h). The synergetic effects between NiCo alloy nanoparticles and the role of CNTs and carbon nanorods are believed to be the major contribution for the improved catalytic activities, including excellent conductivity, dispersed active sites, optimized electronic structure, and three-dimensional (3D) interconnected network structure. This work will facilitate the development of bimetallic alloy-based materials toward ORR and OER electrocatalysts with features of durability, inexpensiveness, and efficiency.

cln_elements.content: The synthesis of NiCo-MOF was based on published literature with some modification. First, a total of 4 mmol of two metallic acetates (Ni­(CH3COO)2·4H2O/Co­(CH3COO)2·4H2O) and 2 mmol 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (DHTA) were dissolved in 50 mL of deionized water, respectively. Then, the solution containing metallic acetate was dropped into another solution containing DHTA with slow continuous magnetic stirring (15 min). Finally, the mixed solution was put into a round-bottom flask followed by magnetic stirring at 100 °C for 60 min. After cooling down to room temperature, earth-yellow sediments were obtained after centrifugation and washed with deionized water and ethanol several times (7500 rpm for 5 min), respectively. During the feeding process, by tailoring the ratio of Ni2+ and Co2+, NiCo-MOF nanorods with different chemical compositions can be obtained, which were named Ni x Co y -MOF (x:y = 4:0, 3:1, 2:2, 1:3, and 0:4).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of NiCo-MOF Nanorods

The synthesis of NiCo-MOF was based on published literature with some modification. First, a total of 4 mmol of two metallic acetates (Ni(CH3COO)2⋅4H2O/Co(CH3COO)2⋅4H2O) and 2 mmol 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (DHTA) were dissolved in 50 mL of deionized water, respectively. Then, the solution containing metallic acetate was dropped into another solution containing DHTA with slow continuous magnetic stirring (15 min). Finally, the mixed solution was put into a round-bottom flask followed by magnetic stirring at 100 °C for 60 min. After cooling down to room temperature, earth-yellow sediments were obtained after centrifugation and washed with deionized water and ethanol several times (7500 rpm for 5 min), respectively. During the feeding process, by tailoring the ratio of Ni2+ and Co2+, NiCo-MOF nanorods with different chemical compositions can be obtained, which were named Ni x Co y -MOF (x:y = 4:0, 3:1, 2:2, 1:3, and 0:4).

cln_elements.content:
The exploring of oxygen electrocatalysts with outstanding durability and efficiency toward the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is greatly desired for zinc-air flow batteries (ZAFBs). Herein, NiCo alloy-based nanoparticles anchored on carbon nanotube-decorated carbon nanorods (CNRs) used as a durable and efficient oxygen electrocatalyst for ZAFBs were obtained from the pyrolysis of NiCo metal–organic frameworks synthesized by a facile oil bath method. By tailoring the ratio of Ni2+ and Co2+, the prepared sample, Ni2Co2-CNR, exhibits excellent ORR (E 1/2 = 0.80 V) and OER catalytic performances (a low overpotential of 310 mV at 10 mA cm–2). Impressively, the ZAFB assembled with a Ni2Co2-CNR catalyst shows a narrow voltage gap and remarkable operation durability with 1200 cycles at 5 mA cm–2 with every cycle of 20 min.

Inspired by the above, in this article, a highly efficient, low-cost, and stable bifunctional electrocatalyst containing NiCo alloy nanoparticles and a small fraction of CNTs, which are tightly anchored and decorated on carbon nanorods, respectively, (Ni x Co y -CNR), is presented. Also, the whole synthetic process is overwhelmingly simple and facile, which only involves an oil bath method and subsequent calcination. The hybrid catalyst with a suitable ratio of Ni2+and Co2+ (Ni2Co2-CNR) shows positive electrocatalytic activities and stability toward ORR (E 1/2 = 0.80 V) and OER (a low overpotential of 310 mV to reach 10 mA cm–2) compared to the 20 wt % Pt/C and IrO2 catalysts, respectively. What is most impressive is that when Ni2Co2-CNR is integrated into the ZAFB, a high peak power density (122.1 mW cm–2) and energy density (784.5 mA h gZn –1) can be achieved. In addition, ZAFBs fabricated with Ni2Co2-CNR also exhibit an anticipated long-time cycling performance without obvious decay (1200 cycles at 5 mA cm–2 with every cycle of 20 mins). The synergetic effects that stem from the carbon framework (carbon nanorods and CNTs) and NiCo alloy nanoparticles are considered as the major contributions for the enhanced electrocatalytic activity.

The XRD patterns obtained from five different samples are presented in l. Ni4Co0-CNR without the addition of Co2+ displays a pure Ni phase and its three distinctive peaks located at 44.5, 51.8, and 76.3° are assigned to the (111), (200), and (220) planes of Ni (PDF#04-0850), indicating that Ni2+ from the precursor of Ni4Coy-MOF is successfully reduced to Ni nanoparticles during the process of calcination. Subsequently, after the introduction of Co2+ in the synthetic steps, the diffraction peaks of the obtained three samples (Ni3Co1-CNR, Ni2Co2-CNR, and Ni1Co3-CNR) shift to lower angles and are located between those of Co (PDF#15-0806) and Ni (PDF#04-0850), demonstrating the formation of single-phase alloyed NiCo nanoparticles. Although the information concerning carbon peaks is not discovered from the XRD results, this phenomenon does not manifest the inexistence of carbon components. Obviously, the Raman spectrum of the five samples is diagnostic of the presence of carbon species. As shown in m, all samples display two peaks centered at about 1335 cm–1 (D-band) and 1585 cm–1 (G-band), respectively. The D-band and G-band derive from the defective carbon (sp3) and graphite carbon (sp2) atoms, respectively. The ratio of I D/I G of Ni2Co2-CNR is 1.01, smaller than those of Ni4Co0-CNR (1.04), Ni3Co1-CNR (1.21), Ni1Co3-CNR (1.06), and Ni0Co4-CNR (1.04), indicative of the improved degree of graphitization of Ni2Co2-CNR. The boosted degree of graphitization is expected to trigger an enhanced electrical conductivity, which favors acceleration of the charge transfer rate during the electrolysis.

XPS was conducted to investigate the chemical composition of all catalysts. As shown in a, the XPS overall survey spectra confirm the existence of C, O, Ni, and Co elements of Ni3Co1-CNR, Ni2Co2-CNR, and Ni1Co3-CNR. Especially for Ni2Co2-CNR, it includes 4.58, 3.98, 87.45, and 3.99 at % Ni, Co, C, and O, respectively, based on the XPS results (Table S2), which is close to the feeding composition in its precursors. Furthermore, it can be observed that the intensity of the Co peak becomes weaker with the reduction of the Co ratio from Ni0Co4-CNR to Ni4Co0-CNR. In contrast, the intensity of the Ni peak becomes strong with the reduction of the Co ratio from Ni0Co4-CNR to Ni4Co0-CNR, which is also in accordance with the feed ratio of Ni2+/Co2+.

The high-resolution of the Co 2p spectrum of Ni0Co4-CNR (b) can be fitted into four components, which are Co0 (779.42 eV and 794.44 eV), Co3+ (795.37 and 780.66 eV), Co2+ (782.48 and 797.54 eV), and satellite structure (786.56 and 803.08 eV). Meanwhile, the peaks of Co0 from Ni1Co3-CNR, Ni2Co2-CNR, and Ni3Co1-CNR were shifted to lower binding energies of about 1.09, 0.75, and 0.71 eV, respectively, with respect to the monometallic Ni0Co4-CNR. Such an observed shift reflects a modification of the electronic structure between the near-surface Co and Ni atoms. It also demonstrates the formation of the NiCo alloy and the existence of bimetallic synergic effects. Such a phenomenon can also be verified from the high-resolution Ni 2p spectra of all samples. As shown in c, the high-resolution Ni 2p spectrum of Ni4Co0-CNR can also be deconvoluted into eight peaks, displaying four Ni species. The peaks at 852.61 and 870.98 eV are attributed to Ni0 in the NiCo alloy. The peaks located at 853.77 and 873.47 eV correspond to Ni3+ the peaks at 855.74 and 877.97 eV are consistent with those of Ni2+, and the other peaks located at 860.70 and 880.81 eV are assigned to the satellite structure. Similarly, the peaks of Ni0 from Ni3Co1-CNR, Ni2Co2-CNR, and Ni1Co3-CNR were also shifted to lower binding energies of about 0.01, 0.39, and 0.03 eV, respectively, confirming the presence of NiCo alloy. Ascribed to the formation of the NiCo alloy, the Co atoms can obtain d electrons from the nearby Ni atoms, increasing the electron-donating feature of the hybrids, which may improve the electrochemical activity. d shows the high-resolution O 1s spectrum, and the peaks at 529.88 and 531.58 eV are attributed to oxygen species.

e,f displays the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm and the corresponding pore diameter distribution curves of Ni x Co y -CNR. Obviously, they all exhibit a typical type IV hysteresis loop, confirming the existence of micro/mesoporosity in the as-synthesized catalysts. In addition, the specific surface area (SSA) and the maximum pore width of Ni2Co2-CNR are measured to be 154.93 m2 g–1 and 23.1 nm, respectively. Also, the sample of Ni0Co4-CNR has no pores according to the pore diameter distribution curve. The mesoporous structure has a positive impact on the mass transfer and rapid diffusion of O2, thus providing a highly accessible surface area and more active sites for the electrolysis.

Electrocatalytic Properties

To assess catalytic performance toward ORR, the five samples’ powder as well as 20% Pt/C were tested for linear sweeping voltammograms (LSV) in O2-bubbled 0.1 M KOH solution with a rotation speed of 1600 rpm at a scan rate of 5 mV s–1. As displayed in a and Table S3, without the addition Co2+ in the precursor, even the diffusion limiting current density of Ni4Co0-CNR does not achieve −4 mA cm–2, whereas after the introduction of Co2+ in the precursor, Ni3Co1-CNR, Ni2Co2-CNR, and Ni1Co3-CNR can reach higher values above −4 mA cm–2, indicating that the synergetic effects between NiCo alloy nanoparticles and carbon nanorods can enhance ORR performance. More remarkably, Ni2Co2-CNR shows pleasurable ORR catalytic activity confirmed by the limiting current density (−5.15 mA cm–2) and half-wave potential (E 1/2 = 0.80 V) being more positive than those of Ni4Co0-CNR, Ni3Co1-CNR, and Ni1Co3-CNR, although they are slightly lower than those of 20% Pt/C. However, with the continuous increase of Co2+ until Ni2+ is totally replaced by Co2+, the limiting current density of Ni0Co4-CNR is still unsatisfactory. All the above discussions demonstrate that Ni2Co2-CNR possesses the best ORR electrocatalytic performances. The excellent ORR activity of Ni2Co2-CNR can further be verified by the Tafel slope displayed in b. It can be seen that the Tafel slope of Ni2Co2-CNR is 83 mV/dec, much lower than that of Ni4Co0-CNR (150 mV/dec), Ni3Co1-CNR (138 mV/dec), Ni1Co3-CNR (123 mV/dec), and Ni0Co4-CNR (127 mV/dec) and even comparable to that of Pt/C (70 mV/dec), which validates the preferable kinetic process of Ni2Co2-CNR toward ORR. The prominent ORR performance of Ni2Co2-CNR may be attributed to the synergetic effects between NiCo alloy nanoparticles and carbon nanorods and high surface area and 3D interconnected network architecture stemming from carbon nanorods and CNTs.

cln_elements.content:
LSV curves of Ni2Co2-CNR at different rotating speeds were also recorded to further gain insight into the ORR kinetics shown in c and Figure S1. Obviously, as the rotation rates increase, so does the limiting current density. The inset of c presents the corresponding Koutecky–Levich (K-L) plots of Ni2Co2-CNR and the lines are linear and parallel, indicating that O2 kinetics on the Ni2Co2-CNR catalyst follows first-order reaction kinetics. Also, the calculated electron transfer number (n) is determined in the range of 3.85–3.94, indicating that a typical four-electron reaction pathway is dominat during the ORR process for Ni2Co2-CNR. The n values for other samples are displayed in Figure S2. In addition, the n and peroxide yield (HO2 – %) are obtained according to the rotating ring disk electrode (RRDE) curves. As shown in Figure S3, Ni2Co2-CNR possesses comparable values of n (3.85) at 0.7 V, which matches well with the above result (the inset of c). Furthermore, the HO2 – % for Ni2Co2-CNR is 7.48% at 0.7 V, disclosing excellent selectivity for the ORR process.

Furthermore, the stability and durability of Ni2Co2-CNR were also tested because of their importance for the ORR reaction. Ni2Co2-CNR displays no obvious recession after adding methanol (3 M) into electrolyte, suggesting the excellent abovementioned property (d). In addition, when Ni2Co2-CNR is subjected to cyclic voltammetry (CV) tests for 4000 cycles, as presented in e, a negligible performance reduction (5 mV) negative shift toward E 1/2 is observed after tests. Figures S4 and S5 display the SEM, TEM, and corresponding mapping images after CV measurements. Clearly, many carbon rods are captured after tests, disclosing no obvious changes about its morphology. Furthermore, it is also interesting to notice that many CNTs marked in Figure S5b,c still can be observed. Figure S5d shows the homogeneous distribution of Ni and Co elements. Further, f displays the i–t curve of Ni2Co2-CNR and 20% Pt/C at a potential of 0.65 V. After about 43,000 s, the prepared catalyst can retain 84.1% of the initial current. On the other hand, its counterpart has only a relative current retention rate of 50.2%, which is ascribed to the corrosion of the amorphous carbon support and the possible Pt detachment and aggregation. In general, the above results reveal the outstanding durability and stability of Ni2Co2-CNR as an ORR electrocatalyst.

Under the same measurement conditions, the OER performances of the NiCo alloy series and the commercial IrO2 catalyst were also investigated and are exhibited in a. It is found that Ni2Co2-CNR not only shows favorable ORR performance but also outstanding OER activity. Apparently, a 310 mV overpotential to achieve 10 mA cm–2 is afforded by the Ni2Co2-CNR, lower than that of other ratios of NiCo alloy catalysts (Table S3) and IrO2. The better performance toward OER of Ni2Co2-CNR can be also validated from the Tafel slope value of all samples shown in b. One can see that Ni2Co2-CNR possesses a Tafel slope value of 135 mV/dec, lower than those of Ni4Co0-CNR (163 mV/dec), Ni3Co1-CNR (163 mV/dec), Ni1Co3-CNR (136 mV/dec), Ni0Co4-CNR (248 mV/dec), and IrO2 (232 mV/dec). This is perhaps attributed to the higher graphitization degree of Ni2Co2-CNR (m) and optimized electronic structure between NiCo alloy nanoparticles (b,c).

Additionally, because of the proportion between electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) and electrochemical double-layer capacitance (Cdl), CV measurements at different scan rates were conducted to calculate the value of C dl so as to further estimate ECSA. As shown in d and Figure S6, Ni2Co2-CNR displays the largest C dl determined to be 44.9 mF cm–2, higher than those of other as-synthesized samples, demonstrating that Ni2Co2-CNR can supply more active sites for redox reactions. The so many active sites of Ni2Co2-CNR is believed to be governed by its unique and abundant carbon structure including carbon rods and CNTs, which can expose more NiCo alloy sites, further resulting in remarkable OER performance.

Likewise, the durability is also a crucial indicator to assess the performance of a catalyst toward OER. Therefore, CV cycling and i–t techniques are carried out to verify the stability of Ni2Co2-CNR. First, as displayed in e, after 4000 cycles of CV cycling, the slight change of overpotential (10 mV) is afforded by Ni2Co2-CNR. Figure S7a shows the SEM image after OER tests of Ni2Co2-CNR. It can be observed that Ni2Co2-CNR keeps its original structure with obvious carbon rods. In addition, the high-resolution Co 2p and Ni 2p spectra after OER tests of Ni2Co2-CNR were also detected and are showcased in Figure S7b,c. However, the potential to achieve 10 mA cm–2 is positively shifted by 140 mV for IrO2. Then, an i–t chronoamperometric response test is conducted and the result is presented in f. After 12 h of continuous operation, the residual current percentage of Ni2Co2-CNR is 90.4%. Consequently, Ni2Co2-CNR also possesses promising durability toward OER processes.

To investigate the potential application of Ni2Co2-CNR in ZAFBs, the ORR and OER bifunctional performances are further characterized by the potential gap (ΔE = E OER(j = 10) – E 1/2). As displayed in c, the Ni2Co2-CNR catalyst exhibits a VG of 0.74 V, lower than that of Pt/C + IrO2 (0.86 V) and some reported transition-metal alloy-based bifunctional catalysts.

Figure S8 displays a ZAFB with Ni2Co2-CNR displays an open circuit potential of 1.61 V after 600 s. b exhibits discharge polarization and corresponding power density curves for ZAFBs assembled with Ni2Co2-CNR and Pt/C + IrO2, respectively. It can be seen that the maximum power density of ZAFBs using Ni2Co2-CNR as the air electrode is 122.1 mW cm–2, higher than that of the Pt/C + IrO2-based ZAFB (93.6 mW cm–2). Galvanostatic discharge curves reveal that Pt/C-based ZAFBs can only maintain about 124.2 h under a current density of 10 mA cm–2. However, the ZAFB using Ni2Co2-CNR as the air cathode can work for more than 200 h although the discharge voltage of Ni2Co2-CNR is lower than that of Pt/C at the initial 100 h. With the continuous consumption of the zinc plate, the electrolyte of the ZAFB began to leak, resulting in the fluctuation of the curve shown in c. The inset of c shows the photograph of the zinc plate after the battery stopped working. The discharge potential plains of the ZAFB at different current densities were also tested and are showcased in d. At 10 mA cm–2, the voltage of the ZAFB equipped with Ni2Co2-CNR is lower than that of the ZAFB fabricated with Pt/C + IrO2. However, at higher current density, the voltage of Ni2Co2-CNR is apparently higher than its counterpart. Even though the current density was returned to 10 mA cm–2, the voltage rebounded to 1.17 V, disclosing a remarkable rate performance for Ni2Co2-CNR. Also, at 5 mA cm–2, the specific capacity of the ZAFB with Ni2Co2-CNR is 784.5 mA h gZn –1 by normalizing to the consumed zinc (e). f presents a ZAFB assembled with the Ni2Co2-CNR catalyst, which lightened a light-emitting diode (LED) board showing “DHU”. In addition, two ZAFB in series can light a LED bulb, demonstrating its potential application.

LSV curves of Ni2Co2-CNR at different rotating speeds were also recorded to further gain insight into the ORR kinetics shown in c and Figure S1. Obviously, as the rotation rates increase, so does the limiting current density. The inset of c presents the corresponding Koutecky-Levich (K-L) plots of Ni2Co2-CNR and the lines are linear and parallel, indicating that O2 kinetics on the Ni2Co2-CNR catalyst follows first-order reaction kinetics. Also, the calculated electron transfer number (n) is determined in the range of 3.85-3.94, indicating that a typical four-electron reaction pathway is dominat during the ORR process for Ni2Co2-CNR. The n values for other samples are displayed in Figure S2. In addition, the n and peroxide yield (HO2 - %) are obtained according to the rotating ring disk electrode (RRDE) curves. As shown in Figure S3, Ni2Co2-CNR possesses comparable values of n (3.85) at 0.7 V, which matches well with the above result (the inset of c). Furthermore, the HO2 - % for Ni2Co2-CNR is 7.48% at 0.7 V, disclosing excellent selectivity for the ORR process.

Furthermore, the stability and durability of Ni2Co2-CNR were also tested because of their importance for the ORR reaction. Ni2Co2-CNR displays no obvious recession after adding methanol (3 M) into electrolyte, suggesting the excellent abovementioned property (d). In addition, when Ni2Co2-CNR is subjected to cyclic voltammetry (CV) tests for 4000 cycles, as presented in e, a negligible performance reduction (5 mV) negative shift toward E 1/2 is observed after tests. Figures S4 and S5 display the SEM, TEM, and corresponding mapping images after CV measurements. Clearly, many carbon rods are captured after tests, disclosing no obvious changes about its morphology. Furthermore, it is also interesting to notice that many CNTs marked in Figure S5b,c still can be observed. Figure S5d shows the homogeneous distribution of Ni and Co elements. Further, f displays the i-t curve of Ni2Co2-CNR and 20% Pt/C at a potential of 0.65 V. After about 43,000 s, the prepared catalyst can retain 84.1% of the initial current. On the other hand, its counterpart has only a relative current retention rate of 50.2%, which is ascribed to the corrosion of the amorphous carbon support and the possible Pt detachment and aggregation. In general, the above results reveal the outstanding durability and stability of Ni2Co2-CNR as an ORR electrocatalyst.

Under the same measurement conditions, the OER performances of the NiCo alloy series and the commercial IrO2 catalyst were also investigated and are exhibited in a. One can see that Ni2Co2-CNR possesses a Tafel slope value of 135 mV/dec, lower than those of Ni4Co0-CNR (163 mV/dec), Ni3Co1-CNR (163 mV/dec), Ni1Co3-CNR (136 mV/dec), Ni0Co4-CNR (248 mV/dec), and IrO2 (232 mV/dec). cln_elements.content: Last but not least, to verify the excellent stability and durability of Ni2Co2-CNR, the galvanostatic cycling test of ZAFBs is further investigated with every cycle of 20 min. As shown in g, at 5 mA cm–2, the battery assembled by Pt/C + IrO2 fails quickly with a limited cyclability of 237 cycles (79 h). However, the battery fabricated by Ni2Co2-CNR displays an outstanding durability for 1200 cycles (400 h). Although, at the first cycle, the VG of Pt/C + IrO2 is 0.83 V (Figure S9), a little lower than that of the Ni2Co2-CNR-based battery (0.85 V) showcased in the inset of g. This may be attributed to the better ORR and OER catalytic activity from Pt/C and IrO2, respectively. Nevertheless, with the increment of cycles, the VG of Pt/C + IrO2 grows to 0.98 V after 200 cycles due to the poor stability of Pt/C or IrO2 while the VG of the battery assembled by Ni2Co2-CNR only reaches to 0.93 V at 500 cycles (the inset of g). This may be ascribed to the compatibility adjusted by the original charging and discharging operation, enhancing the sufficient electrochemical reaction, which is in favor of cycling performance. Consequently, even at 1200 cycles, the VG is merely 1.04 V (the inset of g). Figure S10 displays the SEM images of Ni2Co2-CNR after cycling tests. It can be clearly observed that Ni2Co2-CNR still retains the original rod-like shape, which is in accordance with the initial SEM images (h), demonstrating the prominent stability and durability of Ni2Co2-CNR.
